entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud – F2 billing: Number range inter...
entry.content:
Not sure whether you checked or not. If not, go to Define Number Ranges for Billing Documents in the production system and manually verify that the interval 19 has valid “from” and “to” values. In Public Cloud, number range intervals are not always transported correctly from the quality system to production. Even if the interval exists in your source system, the “from” and “to” numbers might be missing in the target system.

If Flexible Billing Document Numbering is active, the system may dynamically select a number range based on header fields (e.g., company code, billing type). If the logic points to a number range that’s not properly defined or missing, you’ll get this error. Check if flexible numbering is active and review the logic/rules in the configuration environment.

Even though number range key 00 exists, it must be defined for the specific fiscal year. Double-check that the number range for key 00 is maintained for the current fiscal year in the posting company code.

entry.title: Company Structure Overview and duplicate objects displayed
entry.content:
Let's start by defining our Company Structure, usually we find the Business Unit as the highest level in the hierarchy, followed by the Divisions and the rest of the structure is defined using parent child department relationship.

In this scenario our department object will have 2 associations one to division and another one to parent department. 

Because the Company Structure overview relays on the associations to display the structure, the department will be displayed twice, once under the division and another one under the parent department.

Department configuration

Let me show you a workaround to avoid this duplication

1. Add a custom field - division on Department object. this field should be read only

2. We create a Rule triggered on Save on Department object, that automatically populates the data from the standard association field to the new custom_division field in case the Parent department value is null

The custom division field should only be updated in case the Parent Department is not empty

3. Update the Company Structure Overview to display the new field instead of standard association

4. Go to Company Structure Overview and display the results. The Department no longer appear duplicated

5. Position and job info filters to departments will remain the same

Hope this can make your Company Structure easier to set up and maintain 

Please also take into consideration the useful information and configurations shared on IDP ( implementation Design Principle) IDP Employee Central Core Hybrid - Organization Structure Design Consideration V2.0.pdf

This IDP will provide you also more clarity on the set up and design of the Organization Structure

entry.title: Re: How to enable smart link with Action CDS view tile
entry.content:
Hello @Raghavendar 

In addition to @Maciej__Galica  comment,

You cannot restrict the Smart Link popover to a single action. By design, it lists all target mappings for a semantic object
To navigate directly to the Manage G/L Account app, use intent-based navigation via DataFieldForIntentBasedNavigation instead of @Consumption.semanticObject.

Useful SAP Documentation References

Smart Link popover behaviour (lists all actions):

  • SAP Fiori Design Guidelines – Smart Link
  • SAPUI5 API Reference – sap.ui.comp.navpopover.SmartLink

Intent-based navigation annotations:

  • SAP Help Portal – ABAP CDS: DataFieldForIntentBasedNavigation

Target app reference:

  • SAP Fiori Apps Library – Manage G/L Account Master Data (V2) (App ID F0731A)


Smart Link is a popover with an unlimited number of actions. Use DataFieldForIntentBasedNavigation with General Ledger Account/manage for a straightforward, one-click access to Manage G/L Account.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Highlights of Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition 2025
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 were released today.

Transportation Management is included in this release and offers impressive innovations.
I am excited to share the latest updates with you in this blog post.

One of the most important highlights of this release is the integration of Transportation Management with

Lean Service Procurement

The biggest advantage of working with Lean Service Procurement in TM is that freight charge invoicing is much more transparent, and invoice verification is simplified, reducing total operating costs.

This contrasts with the established integration (which is still available) of invoice verification with TM, where only the total TM costs were visible on the invoice. Now, charge items are displayed individually on the invoice. For the user responsible for checking invoices, it's much easier to validate the correctness of an incoming invoice against the calculated costs from TM because they can see all the charge items in the system and easily compare them with the individual items on an incoming (B2B or paper) invoice.

Overall, a harmonized process is introduced across S/4HANA for invoicing purchased services, and visibility into the freight charge invoicing process is significantly improved. Additionally, universal parallel accounting is enabled.

 

Graph of the Integration of the new lean service procurement process into Transportation Management and Invoicing

 

How is this new process enabled? The basis for this new type of charge settlement is that charge types are directly matched with independent service materials and dependent charge types are linked with the technique of conditions. This makes it easy to visualize unplanned charges during the invoicing process and allows purchasers to enter them directly into the manual invoice verification process.

Freight Order charge items, mapping and visibility in the carrier invoice

 

Of course, the carrier may have already made corrections to charge items in advance, e.g., in collaboration apps during ERS (evaluated receipt settlement) or self-billing, to avoid discrepancies in invoice verification. This means that a dispute case was created and resolved in advance. Dispute management in TM is also supported with lean service procurement integration.

The new lean service procurement introduces new apps for the accrual process. With these apps create and post accruals can be triggered after a certain status is reported in a freight execution document (e.g., checked out, departed, shipped on board, or uplifted). 

 New Apps for Freight Accruals with snapshot of all charge items of a freight document

 

Along with this innovation, background reports are provided to automate the process.

Another important aspect is that customers upgrading to the new Lean Service Procurement integration are supported with reports to ensure a smooth transition and consistent settings in agreement management.

The new Lean Service Procurement integration also enabled and enhanced the natively available Carrier Collaboration Apps. What's new with the

Carrier Collaboration Apps

In previous releases, it was already possible to manage freight order charges or create an invoice with carrier collaboration apps. This process has been improved in many ways. For example, you can now create and recall invoices submitted in the self-billing process. This feature is useful when the LSP or carrier wants to correct and resubmit an invoice. If the carrier has changed or added charge items, meaning a dispute exists, the dispute case will be canceled automatically when the invoice is recalled, depending on the status of the dispute case.

A further invoicing feature is the ability to create a note when creating a credit memo to explain why a credit memo is being created.

Recall of an invoice

A very useful new feature for managing invoices is the ability to delete or exclude charge items from an invoice.

In a freight order, additional invoicing parties may exist, e.g., for charging service or pre-carriage fees. Now, it is possible to manage charges for a freight order and run all invoicing processes for additional parties in Collaboration Apps the same way as for the main carrier. Only the relevant charge items will be displayed to the relevant carriers, as calculated in the freight order.

Display of charge items in the invoicing app of the carrier collaboration apps

 

Many transportation planners have been waiting a long time for the following great innovation.

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) in the Transportation Cockpit

In this release, we focused on the most important KPIs for road transportation and made them available for the freight order list, freight unit stages, and truck resources.  In total, we deliver 93 standard KPIs from various categories.

  • Utilization
  • Quantity (weight, volume, etc.)
  • Distance
  • Duration
  • CO2 emissions
  • Costs

The KPIs displayed are defined with the help of a KPI profile and can be enhanced based on customer needs.
The profile allows you to freely define the sequence and choose the respective KPIs, as well as the display of delta values, previous values, or colors. These can be updated depending on set thresholds.
KPIs are calculated and updated after each planning step. This allows planners to quickly see how KPIs change and visualize their impact next to the KPI.
This improved transparency of KPIs during the planning process helps planners make better decisions, which ultimately leads to improved transportation plans.

Display of the KPIs and impact after planning changes

 

There are also many other enhancements in the transportation cockpit. I would like to mention the most important ones. Further details can be found here: KPI area in Transportation Cockpit

  • Distance (Empty) and Distance (Loaded).
    We introduced new fields for distance (empty) and distance (loaded) for road and rail freight orders, as well as for container, trailer, and railcar units in the Transportation Cockpit and in the single document UIs. This gives planners more transparency into whether a resource is traveling empty or loaded.
  • In the road freight order hierarchy, it is now possible to group by driver. Now, planners can easily visualize the freight orders planned for drivers.
  • CO2 consumption for vehicle types/resources.
    Now, planners can see the CO2 consumption for resources (empty, partly loaded, or fully loaded). This helps them, for example, choose the most efficient resource for manual planning and reduce CO2 emissions.
  • We have added actions and fields in the Transportation Cockpit for subcontracting freight and rail freight orders, consignment orders, and air and ocean bookings.

Various other innovations in Transportation Planning & Network

Various other innovations in Transportation Planning & Network

In addition to the innovations in the transportation cockpit, as with every release, many innovations are provided in transportation planning and networks. Here, I will mention only the major innovations.

  • Extend the capabilities of the freight unit building with more items and further splitting criteria.
    It is now possible for freight unit building to use unloading points as hard split criteria. This is particularly useful for advanced shipping and receiving.
    The system also allows for 999 splits in freight unit building.
  • Consider driver availability in embedded scheduling and the vehicle scheduling and routing (VSR) optimizer. This means that driver unavailability, as defined in the validity period of drivers and resources, is considered. These periods of unavailability are also displayed in the Gantt chart.
  • Replanning and rescheduling by VSR during execution.
    This is an important feature because it allows you to reschedule follow-up activities that have already started or are in progress, enabling you to respond to delays during execution.
  • Appointments in the transportation cockpit.
    We have added fields for appointments to the field list for the transportation cockpit.
  • We have enabled PTV Developer as an additional geographic service provider in SAP HANA Spatial Services Integration. The following service providers are now supported: HERE, TomTom, Trimble, PC*Miler, ESRI, and PTV Developer. 

 

TM based Scheduling for Stock Transport Orders using BPS

As you may know, we introduced TM-based scheduling for sales orders with S/4Hana 2023. With this release, we are introducing TM-based scheduling using Business Process Scheduling for Stock Transport Orders as well. Similar to sales order integration, the scheduling can be even used if the stock transport order is not integrated with TM after the document is saved.

Like with sales order scheduling, the requested delivery is handed over to business processing. Available-to-promise (ATP), in combination with TM scheduling, is called, and, after either backward or forward scheduling, the confirmed delivery dates are returned. During the scheduling process in TM, the durations for loading, transport time, and unloading are calculated. The TM network, including the default route, schedule, straight distance, and relevant Incoterms locations, can be taken into account during scheduling.

Scheduling result in the stock transport order

 

Support cross delivery handling units in combination of EWM and TM in Advanced Shipping and Receiving (Adv. S&R)

With this release, we now support cross-delivery handling units (HUs) within for Advanced Shipping and Receiving Process in an Outbound scenario, for both transportation- and warehouse-driven Adv. S&R. This means it is now possible to combine multiple deliveries into one package if they are going to the same consignee.

In this process, multiple deliveries can be packaged together in the warehouse. These cross-delivery handling units can be integrated into TM in the context of advanced shipping and receiving.

Cross-delivery handling units are displayed as package items in the item hierarchy of the road freight order. 

 

Example how cross delivery HUs are displayed in the freight order

 

Advanced Shipping and Receiving supported for 2-step Stock Transport Order (STO) for EWM managed warehouse

With this feature, FUs are reassigned from outbound deliveries to inbound deliveries as soon as goods are issued from the issuing warehouse. So far, advanced shipping and receiving has not been supported for EWM-managed warehouses within the context of advanced S&R in the STO process. This process gap has now been closed.

Essentially, in an STO scenario, you have already used Adv. S&R for shipping on the outbound side. As soon as you report the goods issue, the FUs are reassigned to the inbound delivery. You can now also execute the process on the receiving side of the STO using the advanced shipping and receiving process if this warehouse is also EWM managed. This was already available previously e.g. for stockroom managed warehouses or LE warehouses. 

 

Reassignment of the freight unit after goods issue on outbound delivery

 

Global Trade Service (GTS) Integration: Update Export declaration after initial declaration

Another helpful new feature, developed primarily by the GTS team, is the updated export declaration. In the past, if there were changes to a freight order or container, the customs declaration had to be canceled, and a new export declaration was required. This is no longer necessary, as it’s now possible to update an initial export declaration with changed information, since GTS can work with updated information from TM.

Innovations in Freight Order Management

Simplified Multimodal Booking for Shippers

Simplified freight booking for ocean and air is already available on the public cloud. They provide a user interface (UI) and process that is closer to the LE-TRA process, offering stage-specific invoicing to carriers. Along with the simplified UI comes the ability to determine a valid agreement for all carriers, as well as the respective charge calculation for multiple carriers. The follow-on processes in settlement, such as the new lean service procurement integration, are also supported.

This simplified UI, with fewer buttons and fields, is now available to private cloud customers through the correct web dynpro application configuration assignment to the booking type.

Simplified Ocean Booking UI

 

Now, cargo that is ready for loading can be used to trigger integration with the Global Trade Service (GTS). This streamlines GTS processes and further automates integration with GTS for trade compliance.

Essentially, this new status can be integrated into the event profile. As soon as the "ready for loading" status is manually set, the customs invoice and export declaration requests can also be sent to the GTS system. With this in place, customs processing can be accelerated.

Another topic that simplifies processes, reduces manual effort, and streamlines freight order execution is the automatic setting of the "ready for transportation execution" status. This means that when any successor event is reported, such as the start of loading, the predecessor event "ready for transportation loading" can also be set.

Consignment orders can now also use subcontracting functionality. This means that freight units with the same source and destination that are grouped into one consignment can be subcontracted to a carrier. As with freight orders, consignment orders can be changed or canceled, and the full communication history is available in the document.

 

Integration to Product Compliance

There are also two new innovations regarding integration with Product Compliance.

While many functions were previously managed directly by TM, they are now called directly from Product Compliance, and the results are received and used in TM.

According to dangerous goods information, we introduced the mixed loading check using Product Compliance in four areas.

First, the mixed loading check has been added to the TM execution document checks. During the document check, all items relevant to Product Compliance are checked to see if they can be transported together. Unlike the current DG classic check, if items are physically separated (e.g., in a truck and trailer or in different containers), the document will no longer be blocked from execution.

Second, the mixed loading check considers product loading incompatibilities during freight unit building.

Third, during VSR optimization, mixed-loading incompatibilities are considered, and items may be planned on separate freight orders.

Lastly, mixed-loading incompatibilities are considered during load consolidation. Consequently, incompatible products are planned into different containers.

 

Mixed loading check during freight unit building and consolidation

 

There are more innovations related to product compliance which are 5 new dangerous goods print forms that are introduced. These are ADR goods note for road Europe, RID goods note for rail Europe, IMO declaration for ocean transports (which is created for the pick-up freight order), US & Canada Bill of Lading and enhancements to the existing CMR/Master Bill of Lading.

Examples of the new dangerous goods print forms

 

BN4L Integration of (Spot) tendering & Dispute Management for Ocean bookings

 

The integration tendering of road freight orders with business network for logistics (BN4L) is available since ever. Now it is also possible to use spot tendering of ocean bookings in the integration with BN4L.

Also, the dispute management functionality that is available since long time in combination with BN4L is now extended to be used with ocean bookings.

This means that the well-known process in case of disputes for charge items can now also be used in ocean related dispute cases.

Clean Core

Clean Core is not only a buzzword. It is very important to our customers to reduce modifications of standard functionality. To improve the Clean Core capabilities in TM, we have introduced further extensibility in TM.

For that purpose, we have delivered the clean core foundation with the help of basic CDS views for 7 nodes of TOR (Transporation Order) objects like TOR Root/Item/Stop/Stage/Execution/DocRef.

With the help of these new basic CDS views it’s much easier for customers to create own customer specific fields, add them to the TM data structures and backend tables and use them in the TM UIs.

Additionally, we have published SOA Webservices, like the SOAP Services for the Agreements in in the business accelerator hub.

Further details on the CDS views for the Transportation Order

 

That's it for today. This was the highlights of Transportation Management in S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2025. 

Stay tuned. S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2025 FP01 is already in the makings. There are great innovations on the way. 
If you are curious, then you can browse through details of upcoming releases and feature packages by checking the Roadmap Explorer for TM.

General further information can be found here:

  • What’s New Viewer
  • SAP TM Product Page on sap.com
  • SAP Community for Transportation Management
  • SAP Transportation Management Group on LinkedIn

entry.title: Re: SNC Kerberos Registry settings for mass user update
entry.content:
In order to achieve automatic selection of Kerberos profile for SSO, you can refer following solution given in the KBA 3086403 - Selecting a Default Secure Login Client Profile For SAP Application Via Registry-Based Group Policy

Resolution

The use of the "GssTargetName" setting may be made in that regard, since depending on it's value and the application's context, a specific profile will be selected over others.

For that end, Microsoft group policies must be used to deploy this configuration.

To configure a connection preference for Kerberos/MS CAPI one should follow the description present in the following SAP Help document.

If Secure Login Server profile is used to enroll for the user certificate, then refer to the following SAP Help document to configure group policies.

In the following SAP Help document, the different values for "GssTargetName" are evidenced.

entry.title: The new HCM EvoGuide: How SAP Is Helping HR and IT Leaders Move from SAP ERP HCM to the Cloud
entry.content:
When our team at SAP began creating “Charting a course from SAP ERP HCM to cloud-based human capital management solutions from SAP”, aka the HCM EvoGuide, we knew we weren’t just writing another technical guide. We were building a blueprint for one of the most significant shifts in HR and IT in decades - the move from traditional, on-premises SAP ERP Human Capital Management (HCM) systems to the cloud-based SAP SuccessFactors suite.

This transformation is about far more than technology. It’s about how organizations think about people, data, and change itself. From day one, we saw our mission as helping leaders not just migrate systems, but also to modernize their mindset.

Listening Before Writing

Before we drafted a single line, our SAP Customer Evolution team spent years listening to and learning from customers, partners, and members of SAP’s global HR and IT community. We held workshops with HRGUG, ASUG, and DSAG and their members and interviewed CIOs and HR leaders across industries.

Three common themes emerged:

  1. Complexity: Decades of customization had left many SAP ERP HCM systems deeply entangled. Modernization felt risky.
  2. Uncertainty: With the 2027 end-of-maintenance deadline approaching, organizations knew they needed to act but lacked a clear plan.
  3. Culture: HR and IT often approached transformation differently with one focused on process continuity, the other on innovation.

It became clear that our guide couldn’t just outline migration steps. It had to be a compass that helped leaders navigate choices, anticipate challenges, and manage both technical and human change.  The result is 140 pages of expert content, practical advice and useful links intended to help each customer to evolve HCM in ways that help their organizations not just to survive, but to thrive. 

Designing a Practical Compass

We structured the guide around three questions every leader faces when planning transformation:

  1. Why change? (Strategic Choices)
  2. How to prepare? (Ingredients for Project Success)
  3. With what tools? (Essential SAP Tools)

The first part clarifies why the shift to the cloud is not optional. With SAP ERP HCM reaching end-of-support in 2027 (extended to 2030 for a fee), remaining on-premises means higher costs, limited innovation, and growing compliance risk.

The guide outlines four deployment models - full cloud, core hybrid, talent hybrid, and private cloud, explaining their implications for agility, cost, and integration. Rather than prescribing one path, we aimed to help organizations make informed decisions based on their readiness, vision, and business priorities.

The Clean Core Mindset

One of the most transformative ideas in the guide is the clean core principle. Over the years, we’ve seen customers struggle under the weight of complex, customized systems. What once offered flexibility has become a barrier to agility.

A clean core approach, keeping systems close to SAP standard and building extensions via SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), is the antidote. It allows companies to innovate quickly, upgrade easily, and stay aligned with SAP’s continuous release cycles.

In practice, this means no longer customizing inside the core, but innovating around it through low-code and no-code extensions. The result: more stability, less technical debt, and a foundation that evolves with your business.

Integration: The Hidden Hero

If the clean core is the heart of cloud transformation, integration is its circulatory system. We devoted a large part of the guide to explaining SAP’s “seven suite qualities,” which define how SAP applications work together with consistent UX (SAP Fiori), unified security, harmonized data models, embedded analytics, and coordinated lifecycle management with SAP Cloud ALM.

Integration might sound technical, but its impact is human. It’s what allows an HR manager to see accurate payroll data in real time, or a business leader to access predictive analytics without toggling between systems.

We also explored how SAP Business Data Cloud unites data from HR, finance, and operations through SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud, giving organizations a real-time, AI-ready foundation for decision-making. When HR data connects seamlessly to business data, organizations move from administration to intelligence.

It’s Not an IT Project, It’s a Change Journey

Perhaps the most important message in the guide is simple: moving to the cloud is not an IT project.

It’s an organizational change journey that touches every level of the enterprise. We’ve seen that successful transformations happen when HR and IT work hand in hand, guided by a shared vision and strong leadership sponsorship.

That’s why we introduced the idea of Phase 0,  the critical preparation period before implementation begins. In this stage, organizations align on objectives, assess readiness, define governance, and build internal capability.

We also emphasized SAP Activate and RISE with SAP methodologies, which blend agile delivery with fit-to-standard design and continuous iteration. Transformation doesn’t end at go-live; it’s a living process that evolves with each new release.

The Human Side of Innovation

Technology matters, but so does experience. Employees today expect consumer-grade interactions at work -  mobile, intuitive, and personalized. That’s why we highlighted SAP’s investments in AI and experience-driven design across SAP SuccessFactors.

Our favorite example is Joule, SAP’s generative AI copilot. Joule simplifies HR tasks through natural language, helping employees check time-off balances, understand pay statements, or navigate learning content. For managers, it provides insights into performance trends and engagement levels.

Joule embodies the future of HR, where technology empowers people, not replaces them. Alongside it, SAP’s deep integration with Microsoft Teams and its mobile-first approach ensure that HR happens “in the flow of work,” wherever employees are.

Tools That Turn Vision into Action

We knew that inspiration alone isn’t enough — organizations need tools to act. That’s why Part Three of the guide focuses on practical enablers, including:

  • SAP Readiness Check: to assess current systems and identify dependencies before migration.
  • HCM ROI Calculator: to quantify value and build the business case.
  • SAP Cloud ALM: for implementation governance and lifecycle management.
  • Infoporter and CSV Migration Tools: for seamless data transfer from SAP ERP HCM to SAP SuccessFactors.

We also pointed readers toward SAP Best Practices packages and partner tools on SAP Store, ensuring that no one has to start from scratch. Transformation is a team sport  - and SAP’s ecosystem of partners and user communities makes that collaboration possible.

Lessons We Learned Along the Way

Writing the guide taught us as much as it aims to teach others. A few insights stand out:

  • Transformation is human first. Technology succeeds only when people are ready and empowered to use it.
  • Simplicity is a superpower. A clean core and standardized processes create the freedom to innovate.
  • Integration equals intelligence. When systems connect, decision-making improves.
  • Data is destiny. Clean, well-governed data fuels AI, analytics, and business agility.

Perhaps the biggest lesson is that transformation is ongoing. Cloud adoption is not the end -  it’s the beginning of continuous improvement, innovation, and value realization.

Looking Ahead

The journey from SAP ERP HCM to SAP SuccessFactors represents more than a technological upgrade; it marks a philosophical shift in how organizations manage their most valuable asset — their people.

Our hope is that this guide gives leaders not just the roadmap, but the confidence to take the first step. Whether an organization chooses a phased hybrid approach or a full cloud transformation, what matters most is momentum - the commitment to move forward with clarity and purpose.

Our team sees this work not as a conclusion but as an invitation: to keep learning, iterating, and collaborating as HR and IT evolve together. Because the future of work isn’t just digital -  it’s human at its core.

Download the complete guide: Charting a course from SAP ERP HCM to cloud-based human capital management solutions from SAP: A practical guide for Senior IT Leadership. 

We also invite you to join this conversation in the SAP Community and discover how organizations worldwide are redefining HR for the cloud era.

entry.title: Re: Query on Price Determination and Error Handling Durin...
entry.content:
Hi,

This behavior is standard system design.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the price determination process follows the standard pricing schema, where: The system reads condition records (e.g., from Contracts, Info Records) based on access sequences. If a valid PIR condition record exists (e.g., valid in EINE or condition tables), it is used for pricing —irrespective of the contract validity, provided the condition validity in the PIR itself is valid for the PO date.

The system does not validate contract validity periods during PO price determination unless the PO is created with explicit reference to that contract. Hence, if the PO is not created with reference to the contract, or if the pricing schema still allows PIR conditions to be read, the system will use the PIR price even if the contract is expired.

Currently, there is no standard configuration option in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to automatically trigger a price error or warning if the contract validity period has expired while still allowing PIR-based pricing.

You may consider BAdI where you can Implement own checks before a purchase order is saved (BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO)

Thanks and regards,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: ODN Official Document Numbering fields in Migration C...
entry.content:
Why ODN fields are missing in templates is because, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud uses predefined migration objects in the Migration Cockpit. The AP/AR open item templates do not expose the ODN field even if it's configured in the system. This is because ODN is typically system-generated during document posting, and not considered part of legacy data input.

Some recommended workarounds are

After migrating open items, use “Post Journal Entries” or “Manage Journal Entries” to manually update the ODN field. This requires authorization to edit posted documents, and may be limited by Public Cloud restrictions.

If AR invoices are tied to eDocument numbers, ensure that the eDocument framework is active and configured. You may need to reprocess or regenerate eDocuments post-migration to align with legacy numbers.

One strategic tip would be if ODN values are critical for compliance or audit, consider storing them in a custom field or reference field during migration, and then mapping or linking them post-migration using a report or reconciliation logic.

entry.title: Re: Production order archive issue
entry.content:
Below are some possible reasons for INSMK change without direct log

1. System-Driven Update via Inspection Lot
Even if the inspection lot shows no issues, closing or usage decision on the lot can trigger a change in stock type (e.g., from quality to unrestricted). This update may reflect back on the production order’s stock assignment without logging a direct change in the order itself.

2. Indirect Change via Goods Movement (MB31 / MIGO)
A goods receipt or reversal posted against the production order could alter the stock type. These movements update INSMK but do not trigger a change log in the production order header or status.

3. Background Job or Enhancement Logic
Some systems have custom logic or user exits that adjust INSMK during batch jobs or cleanup routines. If such logic was triggered in the current year, it could silently update the stock type.

4. Change via CO02 Without Logging
If someone accessed the order via CO02 and changed the stock type on the goods receipt tab, it may not generate a change log unless the header or status was altered.

5. Archiving Pre-Check Logic
The archiving job may internally validate stock type and skip orders with non-standard INSMK values, even if the order is technically closed.

To investigate further

  • Check Goods Movement History: Use MB51 or COOIS to trace any movements linked to the order in the current year.
  • Review Inspection Lot Events: Use QA03 to see if any usage decisions or lot closures occurred recently.
  • Audit Enhancements: Review any custom logic in CO02, MB31, or archiving pre-check routines.
  • Use Table AUFK / AFKO: Compare timestamps and stock type fields to detect silent updates.

entry.title: Re: Question about scope item 3L5 and 3Y0 (Liquidity Plan...
entry.content:
Dear @ai_takahashi,

In scope for example 3L5 there are some prerequisites like master data, roles and set-up instructions (below link to PDF file)

 

https://support.sap.com/content/dam/SAAP/Sol_Pack/S4C/Library/Setup/3L5_Set-Up_EN_XX.pdf

J78 (Advanced Cash Operations) is not a prerequisite to activate or use 3L5 (Liquidity Planning) or 3Y0 (SAP Liquidity Planning for S/4HANA Cloud) in SAC. You can set up the S/4HANA<->SAC liquidity planning integration without J78.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/186460fdc35a4b64a713da9bb00deb1e/39e81b8f567d415185768de918b5092d.html?version=2508.500

 

When scope J78 is important:

  • Cash Management, some cash-ops apps and business catalogs (e.g., SAP_FIN_BC_CM_CASH_OPS_PC explicitly require scope item J78 to be active. If you need those apps/authorizations as part of your liquidity proces.

Link: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3465570

 

  • Liquidity analysis scenarios: On SAP Community i will find discuss liquidity analysis leveraging BFB (Basic Cash Operations) and/or J78. That indicates optionality based on desired functionality depth, not a hard dependency for SAC integration.

Link: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/liquidity-analysis-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13534661

  • Additionally, the file

     

    does not show any dependencies or requirements to run the process

 

Recommendation:

  • If your goal is planning in SAC with data from S/4HANA Cloud (3Y0) and standard Liquidity Planning (3L5), you can proceed without J78.
  • Activate J78 only if you need the Advanced Cash Operations apps, authorizations, or the enhanced operational cash features in your process

Best Regards

Dawid

entry.title: Re: HOW TO MAKE CONTROL CODE (HSN CODE) AS MANDATORY FIEL...
entry.content:
Hi,

HSN/SAC code cannot be a mandatory field in Financial transactions.

As it is a localization field hence cannot be made part of the standard field status group.

Transaction could also be used for internal document postings example within a plant where GST number is not required in those case the field HSN/SAC cannot be made mandatory.

User has to enter HSN/SAC number manually.

 

Please submit an improvement request in the customer influence portal 

SAP Customer Influence enables customers to submit improvement requests and to openly vote on them.

These voting results inform SAP of product enhancements and changes customers are most interested in seeing in future releases.

1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

2. Register and accept the Terms of Use

3. Choose a session of your interest

4. Create and submit your improvement request

5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thanks and regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: SuccessFactors adapter not fetching data in SAP CPI
entry.content:
Hi Experts

I have a really strange bug.  There is an iflow in our system that is supposed to fetch and sync data from SuccessFactors to an external servers. The fetched data shows up as attachment in the CPI monitoring. It is working perfectly fine in our dev and test tenant. But when the client is trying to run it, it completes the run successfully but does not fetch any data at all. I am at a loss to understand what is going wrong. The endpoints they are using are exactly the same as ours. I asked them to run it in trace mode and share the results. Here is what they found -

This is showing up after a groovy script -

I am not sure why this error is coming up for them. Here is the "Set Content Name ppty" Script

/* Refer the link below to learn more about the use cases of script.
https://help.sap.com/viewer/368c481cd6954bdfa5d0435479fd4eaf/Cloud/en-US/148851bf8192412cba1f9d2c17f4bd25.html

If you want to know more about the SCRIPT APIs, refer the link below
https://help.sap.com/doc/a56f52e1a58e4e2bac7f7adbf45b2e26/Cloud/en-US/index.html */
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import java.util.HashMap;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonOutput;
import groovy.json.*;


def Message processData(Message message) {
    //Body
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
    def jsonSlurper = new JsonSlurper();
    def payload = jsonSlurper.parseText(body);
    
    if (payload['root']['value'] == "") {
        message.setProperty("contentName", 'Not found');
    } else {
        def tyOfValue = payload['root']['value']['componentTypeID']
        message.setProperty("contentName", tyOfValue);
        
    }
    
    
    return message;
}

 For context, they are getting the payload when trying via postman. I am completely lost on this and any help will be appreciated.

Thank You

entry.title: Re: UPDATE PAN ON VENDOR MASTER DATA
entry.content:
Hello @acnascimento_06101,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the India PAN field (J_1IPANNO) on Supplier: Country-Specific (India) is not available via API_BUSINESS_PARTNER, and no supported BAdI exists for customising it. SAP KBA confirms No API to Retrieve PAN in Supplier Country Specific Enh Tab — https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3573075

What should you do?

Maintain via UI: Maintain Business Partner → Supplier (Fin. Accounting) → Supplier: Country-Specific (India).

Mass updates (if available in your tenant template): Manage Mass Maintenance – Business Partners (New)-https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/a20bc500ed9b47658a148c50d72d6062.html

Read/report PAN (not update) via CDS: use I_Supplier → field BUSINESSPARTNERPANNUMBER — KBA: https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3584814

If this is business-critical, you might open an SAP incident and submit a Customer Influence request to expose PAN in the BP API.

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: HTTP Content Server all communication via SAP server?
entry.content:
We found the following:
The SAP TCODE OAG1/OAG4 setting of

'Deactivate Data Provider Cache' influence if SAP IP or Client IP arrived on 3rd party content server.

 

  • Unchecked:      'Deactivate Data Provider Cache'  SAP IP showing up in 3rd party content server
  • Checked:            'Deactivate Data Provider Cache' End User Client IP shows up in 3rd party content server.

 

SAP help on this:

Deactivate data provider cache

 Access Without Data Provider

Indicator that controls whether the URL for a displayed document is temporarily stored in the cache on the SAP application server.

 Indicator not set (standard setting): The URL is stored in the cache.

Indicator set: The URL is not stored in the cache.

  

We notice on other customer and the SAP community said: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/oag1-transaction-settings-effects/ba-p/12950339

The recommendation is to set it (that is, deactivate the DP cache). I've found many problems when the DP cache its used, i.e the DP_ERROR_GENERAL is definetively related with the DP Cache and most of the times simply checking this flag solves the issue (as explained in SAP note 1503002). On the past, it was more difficult to clean the cache since that option did not exist on OAG1 and it has to be cleaned with the help from note 629139

-------------------------
So bottom line is that the OAG1 cache setting setting make a difference but might come with DP Cache errors (DP_ERROR_GENERAL)

entry.title: Re: Create billing documents from sales orders, not deliv...
entry.content:
Hello @KK9221 

No, not in standard Public Cloud. For items with shipment (stock or physical goods), billing is related to delivery: you generate the invoice from the outbound delivery after PGI, not from the sales order. This follows the standard Sell from Stock (BD9) process. SAP Learning-Understanding the Sell from Stock Process

Why “Copying Control” Will Not Help Here. In S/4HANA Public Cloud, copying control is limited and does not alter an item’s billing relevance. Shippable items are billed at the time of delivery, while order-billed items typically include non-delivery services or billing plans. SAP Support Portal-3269803 - Unable to add new Copying Control for Sales and Billing Documents - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If you need to bill before delivery, utilise down payment requests, pro-forma invoices, or Transition to an order-related billing scenario, such as 2EQ Sale of Services or billing plans; however, the item in question is not relevant to delivery. SAP Help Portal-Extensibility for Electronic Document Processing-Testing the New Process

With best regard

Chuma

entry.title: Assistance Required to Modify NACHA File Format as per Bank Requirements
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

I have a requirement to modify the NACHA file as per the bank’s specifications. The bank requires both the Credit and Debit lines to be included within the Entry Detail Record (6) section.

According to their clarification:

  • A line starting with “22” represents the Credit line, which records the credit side of the transaction (e.g., the vendor or payee account being credited).

  • A line starting with “27” represents the Debit line, which records the debit side of the transaction (e.g., the company’s account being debited).

By default, the standard NACHA file only includes the credit line information. I have modified the file to add a separate section for the debit lines, and it now correctly displays both credit and debit lines.

However, I have encountered an issue in the Batch Control Total (8) section. The field “Entry / Addenda Count” currently shows only the total number of credit lines, whereas it should display the total count of both credit and debit lines. Similarly, the “Entry Hash” field is also calculating only the total of credit lines, and it should reflect the combined total of both credit and debit entries.

Due to these discrepancies, the corresponding totals in the File Control Record (9) section are also incorrect.

I have attached a sample output file provided by the bank for your reference. Could you please guide me on how to adjust the NACHA file logic to include both credit and debit lines in the Entry / Addenda Count and Entry Hash fields?

Thank you for your assistance.

You set 0001/0002 in the Migration Cockpit user interface, not in an XML/CSV file.

entry.title: Onboarding 1.0 Decommissioning Procedure & FAQ
entry.content:
Onboarding 1.0 reaches End of Maintenance on May 14, 2026 and is deleted with the 1H 2026 Production release. There’s no automatic migration—plan a reimplementation on the new Onboarding. Begin data exports and decommission planning now. (Dates are subject to change.)

In the 2H 2025 Release, please watch our Configuration Guide for more extensive updates on the decommissioning process. However, this blog is intended to supplement the other resources (Replacement of Onboarding 1.0 with Onboarding) online.

What’s changing

  • Lifecycle

    • End of Maintenance: May 14, 2026 (no code updates, patches, or Compliance updates; minimal support.)

    • Deletion: 1H 2026 Production release (Onboarding 1.0 removed; application & data no longer accessible)

  • Path forward

    • Reimplement to the modern Onboarding solution.

    • This is an entirely different platform & architecture; an automated migration not available.

Why this matters

  • Avoids business disruption at the 1H 2026 release.

  • Ensures legal/compliance readiness (e.g., audit, retention, and I-9 access).

  • Reduces risk by planning exports and cut-over early.

What you should do now

  1. Lock your timeline
    Align on the decommission date with your SAP contact/partner and plan your cut-over milestones backward from mid-May 2026.

  2. Stand up the new Onboarding
    Use best-practice templates and an implementation plan to reconfigure processes, integrations, and permissions.

  3. Export and archive data
    Begin exports well before decommission. After deletion, data is not accessible.
    Prioritize these objects:

    • Reports and Admin Reports

    • Document Center library and contents

    • Compliance materials, such as Form I-9 Section 1 & 2 (with attachments and full audit trail)

    • Custom form templates

    • Audit logs

  4. Decommission cleanly
    Coordinate tenant deactivation and final purge timing. Disable legacy integrations and update SOPs to the new solution. Ensure all standardized exports are stopped and turned off in SuperAdmin, if possible.

  5. Communicate and train
    Notify HR, IT, Compliance, and local admins. It's also best practice to provide quick-start guides for the new Onboarding experience.

Decommissioning checklist (customer actions)

Planning

  • Confirm the final service date for Onboarding 1.0.

  • Define a freeze window for changes to legacy processes/data.

Data

  • Run and validate all required exports (reports, I-9s with audit, document center contents, custom templates).

  • Store exports in your compliant archive with documented retention policies.

Integrations

  • Inventory downstream feeds and middleware flows (e.g., SAP Integration Suite/CPI, SFTP, third-party tools).

  • Redirect or disable legacy connections on cut-over day.

Access

  • Remove user access to legacy features once exports are complete.

  • If needed, request temporary read-only access extension (time-bounded) to resolve late discoveries.

Cut-over

  • Switch to the new Onboarding.

  • Smoke-test critical journeys (external hire, internal/cross-boarding, compliance forms, provisioning, notifications).

Post-cut-over

  • Confirm legacy tenant deactivation and final purge.

  • Validate that no legacy jobs or integrations are still writing/reading.

Enablement & support — who to contact

For assistance, contact your Account Manager or Customer Success contact for:

  • Data export requests

  • Access issues

  • Extension of read-only access, if applicable

They can coordinate with SAP Support on timelines and any environment-specific constraints.

FAQs

What is being deleted/decommissioned, is it the module and our data?
Yes, both. When Onboarding 1.0 is deleted, the application is removed and hosted Onboarding 1.0 data becomes inaccessible. You are responsible for exporting and retaining records needed for legal/compliance purposes before decommission completes.

Will all backups be destroyed?
Operational backups exist solely for disaster-recovery and are rotated on standard schedules. After your tenant is deactivated and purged—and backup rotations complete—there is no recoverable copy of your Onboarding 1.0 data. Plan exports early; after purge and rotation, recovery isn’t possible.

Is any information cached elsewhere, maybe in CPI?
It can be. Check connected middleware (e.g., SAP Integration Suite/CPI), SFTP locations, and third-party systems for message stores, logs, or staged files. Review retention policies and purge those artifacts according to your organization’s data-minimization and regulatory requirements.

What assurance will SAP provide to confirm that any personal data has been removed as per local regulations?
You can request written confirmation of tenant deactivation and purge via an SAP Support case, and coordinate any additional attestation through your Account Manager/Customer Success contact per your data-processing terms. Keep your export receipts and purge confirmations for audit.

Do I need to buy anything new?
Please contact your Account Manager or Customer Success contact for any questions about purchasing for your migration.

Is there an automatic migration?
No. Due to platform differences, a reimplementation is required. Most customers treat this as an opportunity to adopt best-practice configuration and retire customizations that are no longer needed.

What happens if we do nothing?
When the 1H 2026 deletion occurs, Onboarding 1.0 and its data are inaccessible. If you haven’t exported what you need, you risk losing historical records required for audits and legal retention.

entry.title: Re: Business Function Activation for scope items 4HH 4HI has not delivered configuration
entry.content:
Hi Adrian,

Since this is a public forum I have to have a disclaimer that this is general advice only, but I will explain a few concepts so that you understand how all the building blocks fit together. Apologies I know you will understand some of this already.

Also some of this would be different if you were setting up a Greenfield (brand new) S/4HANA system compared to a Brownfield (gone live already) type environment where we need to be a bit more careful in your scenario.

I would first separate the two topics of 'Business Functions' vs 'Best Practices' in your mind as they are different and loosely coupled.

Business Functions

This is how SAP ships some features. Think of it as a feature that is hidden behind a "switch" that you can activate or deactivate (some of them aren't reversible). They do different things so you need to read each individual one, some can automatically add new menu entries, some add new fields and functionality within apps, some open up new customising tables (but don't automatically populate entries), some also include (BC sets - Business Configuration Sets) within them that auto populate configuration in those newly opened tables.

So its a mixed bag and each Business Function needs to be looked into in their own right.

You can get to them in SFW5 in the switch framework, and ours are typically under LOG_EAM*

Someone in the BASIS/Administrator side of your project should be able to provide more advice on these, but if you want reading material:

  • Introduction: Enhancement Packages and Business Functions
  • List of available Business Functions for Asset Management

If I was setting up a new S/4HANA system today, I would be striving for a Fiori first principle, that is then supplemented by older technologies (Web Dynpro / SAP GUI for HTML) when a suitable Fiori app isn't found.

That could be the case for some parts of the system such as Master Data Management. I am mentioning this because in particular some of those LOG_EAM_SIMPLICITY* Business Functions do provide new features for the Web Dynpro apps which are very useful.

I would also do a double check on this site, to confirm that I have activated the required business functions to support the scope items 4HH and 4HI: Required Enterprise Business Functions 

Overall System Setup

When your project is starting, it's shipped with a client 000 that contains some configuration, but that is a reference client and should never be used for configuration. Instead you make a decision whether you want to create: 

  1. A Dev Client with the 000 configuration - This will bring across the typical order and notification types that you would expect in the past (PM01, PM02, M1,M2,M3) etc.
  2. A Best Practices Client - This is a blank client but then allows you to select the best practice scope items that you want to activate in it. For us that would be new Order and Notifications Types (YA01, YA02) etc.
  3. A Merged Client - This starts off with the configuration from 000, but then allows you to activate Best Practices on top. During the BP Activation you typically get some warnings, but then you eventually end up with a system with both order and notification types in it (PM01, PM02, YA01, YA02 etc).

So it sounds like your project went with option #1, but now wants to use the best practice configuration post go-live (which "officially" isn't supported).

It might be a bit retrospective for you now, but if you want more information on this and the official guidance, refer to:

  • Administration Guide to Implementation of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 with SAP Best Practices
  • 3126942 - Jump Start Your SAP S/4HANA 2021 Implementation by Activating SAP Best Practices
  • 2870129 - Best Practice activation on already existing client

Best Practice Items 4HH & 4HI

These are two key SAP notes which are useful for a reference:

  • 3478936 - Getting Started with Phase Model in Maintenance Management (this one has a PDF attachment which is useful)
  • 3365558 - SAP S/4HANA 2023: Restriction Note for Maintenance Order-Related Enhancements

Overall there are two key things:

  1. Officially, we recommend that customers activate 4HH and 4HI via the Best Practices method due to the complexity of the configuration and the amount of tables involved.
  2. Also, stated in the previous comments above, we also state that you should not activate Best Practices in an active client such as your scenario.

Those two statements contradict each other, so now we are in a grey area of what can we do ...

We have had customers and projects manually maintain this configuration, but they have done it in different ways.

Most of the time, you need to download the best practices configuration to *somewhere* from Solution Builder, and then manually maintain those configurations in your DEV system (automatically adding it on a transport to be migrated through your environments / regression tested etc).

That reference config is typically taken from the Implementation Assistant - Solution View (Building Block Builder)

Whether the config is performed manually, a more automated table compare, or even asking BASIS to move a transport between clients is up to you - we don't have any official guidance on this step unfortunately.

I have not gone through all the building blocks myself, but it *should* be contained to the Plant Maintenance module, with some entries touching integration points (such as Procurement Milestones for MM).

I understand that this long winded response may not be exactly what you are looking for, but its my opinion and how I have seen others transition via this method.

Tim

entry.title: Resolving Business Application Studio - BAS: - sh: 1: fiori: Permission denied
entry.content:
Problem:
While running SAPUI5 application in BAS, I am facing the below error:

sh: 1: fiori: Permission denied
Prerequisites:
Created a brand new SAPUI5 Freestyle application.

Configured necessary files:

ui5.yaml

ui5-local.yaml

ui5-deploy.yaml

package.json​
Runtime configuration is already set up.

Solution:

Run the following commands in the BAS Terminal:

 


rm -rf node_modules
npm install
npm run start-fixed
Before running the last command, ensure that your package.json includes the following script:


"start-fixed": "ui5 serve --port 8080"

entry.title: Re: New bank account in new Bulgaria EUR company code
entry.content:
Hello @Dejan_10 

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, keep one Bank Account master and add a House Bank Account Connectivity line per company code (with its own House Bank/Account ID and validity). SAP details this in the Manage Bank Accounts app help and Defining House Bank Account Connectivity topic. SAP Help Portal-Manage Bank Accounts (there are some useful interactive videos)

The Company Code under Entity Details is the Account Holder of the bank account, and connecting other codes via the connectivity tab doesn’t change ownership. SAP’s Bank Account Management explains this concept and how connectivity links accounts. SAP Community-Bank account management in SAP S/4HANA

After adding the connectivity row, complete the company code specifics, such as bank GL mapping and payments. In Public Cloud, set up bank account connectivity and assign reconciliation and clearing accounts for the new company code before processing payments.

If the legal owner is the new company code, set up a separate bank account master with that company as the Account Holder, rather than simply adding connectivity.  

Let me know if it works

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: HSN/SAC CODE FIELD MISSING IN CREATE SUPPLIER INVOICE...
entry.content:
Hello @RAHULSOMANI 

The issue you are facing is because HSN/SAC codes are not automatically derived from non-PO invoices. This can only be the case if the G/L account or service master includes a maintained HSN/SAC code and your system is configured with proper tax determination. You don’t need any custom development for this. You can fix the issue by simply:

  • Maintaining the HSN or SAC code at the G/L account or service master level
  • Verify that the tax code determination and country tax config are active for your relevant business transaction.

These links provide some insights to your question.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/634261119fec4d58970471f2c4a9a740/898549e6663a41c18a82a533f748d3c1.html?locale=en-US

Item with Purchase Order Reference

Manage G/L Account Master Data

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
Good day @Ingrid_at_Applium 

Thank you for your question

For the Accept action to happen, make sure your service quotation type has a valid follow-up Document type and your status schema allow transition to Accepted with an automatic creation action. If those are missing, the system will set the quotation to Under Review instead of Accepted.

Have a look at these links for detailed guidance: Service Quotation (A2X),  Manage Service Quotations & Service Quotation

entry.title: Re: API service quotation A2X: How to turn the service qu...
entry.content:
Hello @Ingrid_at_Applium 

To mark a Service Quotation as Accepted through the Service Quotation (A2X) API, verify that all prerequisites are fulfilled, particularly the Employee Responsible (mandatory since CE2408), and that all target items are complete and priceable. Otherwise, the document will be moved to 'Under Review' instead of 'Accepted'. KBA 3504623 - CE2408 API_SERVICE_QUOTATION_SRV raises message: 'Enter Employee Responsible'

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Issue connecting custom form to MES | "Form is a lega...
entry.content:
Hello @ASG ,

Thank you for your question

CL_FP_FORM_READER only works with Forms by Adobe (SFP/XDP). That error occurs when the template name references a legacy Smart Form/SAP script, which this API can’t read. SAP Help Portal-BTP-Retrieve Stored Form Templates

In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there’s no runtime conversion. Build or copy a standard Adobe form and FDP and run it via Output Management; Adobe forms are the default form technology.   SAP Help Portal-Form Templates

Yes. Public Cloud output relies on Output Control and Adobe forms. If your MES needs PDFs, use the SAP Forms service by Adobe (BTP) REST API with your data. SAP Help Portal-Output Management

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Hiding Next & Previous arrows in Enable Now Trainer
entry.content:
Hi Andrew,

You can turn off the forward and back buttons for content that is launched from a Book object but not for a library.  When you click on a Book object, there is a group of properties called Book Reader.  You have the ability to turn off the forward and back navigation for that block of content using one of the settings in the Book Reader section. 

 

 


You can also turn off navigation in the Trainer Global > Control Bar section of the Playback Settings but this only impacts the Trainer for Simulations and Book Pages.  The forward and back buttons are still there in the library.

 

 

Regards
Shane
